reporting-org.narrative: FONDS VOOR ONTWIKKELINGSSAMENWERKING - SOCIALISTISCHE SOLIDARITEIT VZW

title.narrative: PROG 2017-2021_Outcome_Organizations of people in precarious living conditions have contributed to the improvement and the enforcement of labour rights and the right to social protection, including the right to health, with attention to the interests of both men and women.

description.narrative: The programme in South Africa focusses both on ILO pillar 2 and 3 of decent work, i.e. on improving access to labour rights and the right to social protection and health for the beneficiaries and members of our partners’ organisations. The beneficiaries are people in precarious living and working conditions, mainly farm workers, domestic workers and casual/temporary/informal workers that try to organize themselves to change their circumstances and to demand their rights. A specific focus is put on the most vulnerable, e.g. migrant workers, women workers and young workers. Our partners provide education and information on rights, on organizing and on the political and socio-economic context; they build the confidence and empower their members/beneficiaries, specifically women, and stimulate them to unite in order to demand their rights and shift unbalanced power relations in society. In addition to mobilizing communities and workers, our South African partners will also try to have an impact on decision making processes and the drafting, amending and enforcing of new and existing laws. They will do so through participating in social dialogue or advocating for the creation of broad based social dialogue or collective bargaining platforms, accessible to vulnerable groups. They will support active community participation and awareness and they will try to make the voices of precarious workers and communities heard.

title.narrative: Organizations of people in precarious living conditions have contributed to the improvement and the enforcement of labour rights and the right to social protection, including the right to health, with attention to the interests of both men and women.
Level of improvement in access to the right to social protection, including the right to health, as experienced and indicated by the target groups of the partners.

comment.narrative: Representatives of our partners’ target groups identify the following problems related to access to social protection and health: Vulnerable (farm worker/rural) communities: - lack of knowledge about social protection and health rights, including SDH, gender and the impact of environmental issues - lack of confidence in and access to state institutions to demand rights; - lack of unity and solidarity around health; lack of community participation and mobilization around health; - lack of staff & resources in public health care system; disrespectful treatment of vulnerable groups; lack of information; long distances, long waiting times - lack of government support to health committees and to community participation; no prioritization of equitable, fair and quality primary health care by government; delayed implementation of a national health insurance scheme Specific for farm workers: At the work place: unsafe working environment; lack of protective clothing; harsh physical labour; no sanitation; discrimination, sexual harassment and racism by the farmer towards the (women) farm workers Social determinants of health: Evictions; poor housing conditions (on farms and in townships/informal settlements); lack of access to water and electricity; food insecurity; debt; sexual harassment and gender based violence; alcohol- and substance abuse; teenage pregnancies; violence; high prevalence of HIV/aids and of chronic diseases; low self-esteem and confidence; mental health problems

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 2 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health.

Actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 2 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health. Firstly, as a result of the interventions of WFP, farm women in the Western Cape province are now aware of their rights, have a better understanding of the social determinants of health that impact their communities, and are also able to organise themselves and their communities to address these issues. This has led to a number of key victories including the provision of a mobile clinic by the Department of Health, which has in turn made it possible for farmworker communities to receive the healthcare services they need, without having to travel long distances to clinics, or incur costs associated with this travel. Through the work done by WFP, some farm workers have been able to access protective clothing, improved housing and sanitation. Secondly, in addition to the work done in farmworker communities, WFP and its beneficiaries have been a strong ally and voice in the fight against GBV and femicide at local, provincial and national level. As a result, farm women are now able to challenge national functions of government directly and shift the tone and content of discourse regarding gender based violence in South Africa.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements in at least 3 problems, identified by the target groups, concerning access to the right to social protection, including the right to health.

Building on the achievements in year 3, the following improvements to the mentioned challenges have been achieved:
WFP trained more than 577 women in the past 5 years, next to the 100's of women reached through Indaba's and information sessions, e.g. on Covid-19 and vaccinations. The self-confidence, agency and activism of WFP-trained farmwomen was increased and strengthened during this period. Farmwomen’s empowerment was manifested in different ways. Firstly, women were capacitated to provide advice and support to other farmwomen with respect to health rights and GBV. Secondly, they mobilised and organised their communities around issues of local importance – e.g. service delivery at clinics and police stations. This included various local actions, like pickets. Thirdly, farmwomen demonstrated great self-confidence in their deliberations and engagements with senior government officials, including MECs and Station Commanders. This empowerment led to specific results of mobile clinic buses for isolated farming communities, improvements on local health facilities as far as the building of a new clinic in the Northern Cape, under pressure of WFP activists. For the first time, WFP embarked on various and systematic engagements with men around GBV, including area-based community dialogues and capacity-building workshops. These provided men with a platform to engage on GBV for the very first time. There were discernible changes in men’s attitudes and behaviours.
Over the five-year period, various women were elected to serve on Clinic Committees and Hospital Boards, which ensured that the needs of farm workers and dwellers were on the agendas of these structures. Furthermore, WFP has established and strengthened its relationship with the provincial and district offices of the Department of Health.
Due to food shortages resulting from the Covid-19 pandemic, WFP intensified their focus on women’s agro-ecological food gardens. This has proven to be very successful, and have ensured that women have been able to provide their families with food security.

title.narrative: Level of improvement in access to labour rights and reduction in labour market flexibility and informalisation as experienced and indicated by the target groups of the partners.

comment.narrative:
Representatives of our partners’ target groups identify the following problems related to labour rights:
General for all precarious workers: - very low wages - no adequate access to social protection (paid maternity leave, UIF, COIDA, …) and poor health and safety regulations - decrease of permanent employment, high job insecurity and large scale use flexible labour (seasonal labour, labour broker work or agency, consecutive temporary and parttime contracts, community ‘volunteers’) - lack of: knowledge on labour rights; confidence to demand rights - lack of: enforcement of labour laws, inspections; compliance of employers with labour laws - lack of unity/solidarity and low levels of organizing and representation of precarious workers - unequal access to state institutions to demand rights - historically skewed and exploitative power relations: discrimination, racism, sexism, harassment - xenophobia towards migrant workers, patriarchal relations; - differences in wages, benefits and working conditions between permanent and nonpermanent workers
Specific for Farm Workers: - lack of freedom of association; - increase in seasonal labour, mainly for women
Specific for Domestic Workers: - domestic work not considered as actual; work; high dependence on employer; high vulnerability; exclusion from COIDA - lack of freedom of association; isolation - increase in non-permanent employment through exploitative agencies and labour brokers

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 2 problems concerning the availability of and access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation.

Actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 3 problems concerning the availability of and access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation. In the Western Cape province, where ILRIG, CSAAWU and WFP operate, FOS partners have been successful in helping workers self-organise into community and workplace-based structures that allow them to collectively fight for their labour and health rights. For example, members of CSAAWU have successfully organised a number of strike actions that even gained international recognition including the 2016 Robertson Winery Strike and the 2019 Oak Valley Strike. Through these actions, workers have scored a number of historic victories including wage increases, permanent contracts and improved housing and water infrastructure. Another example is ILRIG, which through its annual Globalisation School, provides workers and their communities with education and training on neo-liberalism and its impact on not just the world of work, but the working class as a whole. While most of its activities are implemented in the Western Cape province, SADSAWU has been involved in a number of national campaigns on issues affecting domestic workers including the need for a living wage and exclusion from the Compensation for Occupational Injuries and Diseases Act (COIDA). This has contributed to increased awareness of issues affecting domestic workers and enabled domestic workers to see what they can achieve when they are organised. The same levels of solidarity have also been noted in Gauteng province, where CWAO, through its Simunye Workers' Forum, supports precarious workers in self-organising and fighting for their labour rights. As a direct result of this intervention, over 12 000 workers now have permanent contracts which in turn means increased wages, greater job security and benefits such as medical aid and provident fund membership. This is an important achievement because going forward, CWAO will be able to use these successes to expand its services and help unorganised precarious workers such as labour broker workers to access their rights and build solidarity in the workplace.

Representatives of our partners’ target groups have indicated that actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to at least 4 problems concerning the availability of and access to labour rights and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation.

Actions of the partners contributed to improvements related to more than 4 problems concerning the availability of and access to labour rights, and reduction of labour market flexibility and informalisation. Building on the achievements of year 3, these are some of the additional achievements:
SADSAWU achieved, after years of lobbying with government and even taking it to constitutional court, the inclusion of domestic workers in the Compensation for Occupational Injuries and Diseases Act (COIDA). This means a significant improvement in the social protection of the more than 900 000 domestic workers in South Africa.
Furthermore, there was a big increase of minimum wage for domestic workers to 88% of the National Minimum Wage (NMW) in 2021, with the promise for it to be equalised with the NMW in 2022. Farm workers have been included in the NMW since 2021 as well, where they were previously paid below the NMW.
CWAO assisted more than 11 000 workers who were made permanent, with significant wage and conditions of employment improvements. CWAO provided + 45 000 workers with legal advice, rights access support and legal representation. In addition, CWAO, in cooperation with other partners, successfully put the government under pressure to include informal workers in the government's Covid-19 Temporary Relief Scheme (TERS) during Covid-19. This benefited millions of precarious workers, including farm workers and domestic workers.
Since the start of the programme in 2017, CSAAWU has gained a solid reputation as a hardworking and reliable union, even in current environment in which trust in unions has declined. As a result of the work done by the union, farm workers are conscious of their constitutional and labour rights, believe in themselves and are empowered to take action to demand their rights. Several workplaces now have functional workers committees that work closely with CSAAWU organisers to enforce labour rights across a number of themes including housing and sanitation, occupational health and the rights of women workers.These actions are expected to have long-term implications and contribute to the improved well-being and reduced vulnerability of farm workers and their communities.
